entry.title: Re: WPDTC tcode calculation of PDT and deviation calculated?
entry.content:
From your description:

PO item 20 shows material 5068888.

PO history for that item shows material 4080737 ‚Äî this suggests a material substitution or service/consumption posting where the GR document is linked to a different material number in the history.

For information, WPDTC is likely matching on vendor + info record + plant and pulling in GR quantities for both material numbers, because they share the same purchasing info record or source list entry. It groups historical receipts by material/vendor/plant (and sometimes by purchasing info record) across the analysis period. If the same material / vendor / plant combination appears in more than one PO item or document in the period, WPDTC can:

  • sum the PO quantities from multiple items, or
  • sum the GR quantities from multiple items, but still use a single PO quantity in the denominator.

This can make the ratio look ‚Äúinflated‚Äù compared to what you see in the single PO.

If the total GR quantity it finds is 2 √ó the PO item quantity, the proportion will be 2.0

entry.title: Analyze Diffencies tile process
entry.content:
Before validating the Difference Analyzer, we would like to have some explanation about the content.

As an example, we have the batch number 22L**1G with a difference value of 15 438,64‚Ç¨ with posting date as 09.09.2025. But when I go in Warehouse Monitor APP to see the movement on this specific batch number, I can see that the batch and the product was in the system since June.

Can you give us some explanation ? 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Analyze Diffencies tile process
entry.content:
The Difference Analyzer in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is used to reconcile stock differences that arise during physical inventory processes. When you notice a difference value, such as 15,438.64‚Ç¨ for batch number 22L**1G, it indicates a discrepancy between the book value and the actual count of inventory.

For your specific case, the batch and product being in the system since June suggests that the difference might be due to transactions or adjustments made after the initial entry.

  • The Warehouse Monitor shows the physical movements of the batch, such as receipts, transfers, and issues, since it was created in the system (June in your case).

  • The Difference Analyzer compares financial or inventory values at a certain point in time, which can highlight discrepancies between book and actual stock or adjustments, not the entire movement history.

Therefore, it is possible for a batch to exist in the warehouse since June, but the Difference Analyzer reflects a specific discrepancy or posting occurring in September.

For more detailed analysis, you can use the ‚ÄòAnalyze Differences‚Äô app to view cumulative and detailed differences, and post corrections as needed.

For further information, please check: Warehouse Management - Analyze Differences 

 

Best regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Posting Output Tax in Customer Down payment Request using Milestone Biling
entry.content:
Hello ,

I am creating a down payment request using the milestone billing plan in the sales order.

In the current accounting document generated for the down payment request, I see only one line posted to the noted item GL, showing both the down payment and tax amounts. The actual accounting entry only occurs when the incoming down payment is posted through transaction F-29.

However, as per legal requirements in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, the business needs output tax to be posted and reported to the tax authorities at the time of creating the Down Payment Request/Advance Invoice itself.

The expected accounting postings are as follows (Total Invoiced Amount = USD 256.30, Down Payment = 20% = USD 51.26, Tax Rate = 15%):

1. Issuance of Advance Tax Invoice / Down Payment Request

  • Dr Customer A/R (including tax) .................................... 58.95

  • Cr Down Payment Clearing ‚Äì Special GL (net) ............. 51.26

  • Cr Tax Payable (VAT Output) ............................................ 7.69

2. Receipt of Advance Payment from Customer

  • Dr Bank (including tax) ......................................................... 58.95

  • Cr Customer A/R (including tax) ......................................... 58.95

3. Issuance of Final Tax Invoice

  • Dr Customer A/R (including tax) ........................................ 235.80

  • Dr Down Payment Clearing ‚Äì Special GL (net) ............. 51.26

  • Cr Sales Revenue ....................................................................... 256.30

  • Cr Tax Payable (VAT Output) ............................................ 30.76

Note: If possible, the net VAT on the balance payment should be reflected as a single line.

Could you please advise how these desired postings can be achieved?

Regards

Mohammed Roshan

entry.title: The ‚ÄúExport and Rename‚Äù Feature We Developed on SAP Engineering Control Center (ECTR-PLM)
entry.content:
1. ‚ÄúExport and Rename‚Äù Feature We Developed on SAP ECTR

VIDEO

Current Situation and Challenges
SAP ECTR provides a powerful solution for managing CAD and non-CAD documents. However, users faced some difficulties, especially during export processes:

  • Documents were exported with the system-defined names assigned by ECTR. This made it difficult for users to identify the correct document among exported files.

  • For CAD documents, especially when sharing CATProduct structures with suppliers, original file names were not preserved, forcing users to manually rename documents.

  • To export multiple documents, users first had to gather them under a single folder.

  • Similarly, CATProduct structures also required additional steps of organizing them into folders within ECTR.

These processes caused time loss and increased the risk of errors.

Our Solution: Export and Rename
To improve the user experience, we developed a new function called ‚ÄúExport and Rename.‚Äù

  • A new menu option was added in ECTR for each document: Export and Rename.

  • When the user selects one or multiple documents, they are directly exported to the desktop into a folder containing the current date and time, with their original names preserved.

  • When CATProduct documents are selected, they are automatically exported together with all their sub-components.

  • The system provides a warning if the user attempts to export an outdated version of a document:

    • OK ‚Üí The latest version is exported.

    • Cancel / X ‚Üí The selected version is exported.
      This prevents the risk of sharing outdated versions.

  • When CATProduct files were exported and opened in CATIA, as you may expect, links were broken. We also solved this issue. Along with each CATProduct, a CATIA macro is automatically exported. When the user runs this macro inside CATIA, all component links are repaired within seconds, and the structure opens without issues.

  • Additionally, we block the export of documents that are not in FR (Final Released) status. This ensures that only approved documents can be exported.

Added Value for the User

  • By preserving original file names during export, search and sharing processes became faster.

  • Automatic export of CATProduct structures eliminated manual operations.

  • Outdated version sharing was prevented, ensuring data accuracy and security.

  • FR status control enforced process discipline, allowing only final approved data to be shared externally.

  • Thanks to the CATIA macro, link repair is completed within seconds, ensuring uninterrupted workflows.

üìåWith this development, SAP ECTR users now experience a faster, safer, and more user-friendly export process.
I would also like to thank Ersin TAYAN from INTEGRANS for his valuable contribution to the project.

entry.title: Re: Usage jconn42.jar with Java application server (wildf...
entry.content:
Here is a more detailed description of the issue in the JDBC Driver bundled with the SAP ASE 16.1 database.

Basically it invokes an API which shouldn't be used by application code: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.logging/java/util/logging/Logger.html#setParent(java.util.logging.Logger);

EAP is smart enough to realize it and throws an exception: https://github.com/jboss-logging/jboss-logmanager/blob/main/src/main/java/org/jboss/logmanager/Logger.java#L370-L377;

We would like to report a bug to SAP but we don't know how

entry.title: Re: Posting Output Tax in Customer Down payment Request u...
entry.content: @mroshan881 The standard way to handle this in SAP for GCC countries is to use a specific billing type for the down payment that is tax-relevant. This means the system will calculate and post tax at the time of billing (creating the down payment request), not at the time of payment.This requires a customizing change and a different transaction than the standard milestone billing down payment process.

entry.title: Kickstart Your SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
All you need to know and where to start

You may have come across articles, presentations, interviews or discussions about SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You heard the term quite often, but you might still be asking:  

  • What exactly is SAP BTP?
  • Why is SAP BTP important?
  • And how do I begin exploring SAP BTP‚Äôs potential?
  • How does SAP BTP fit into the clean core strategy?

You‚Äôre now at the right place.

Whether you're a decision maker looking to drive IT strategy, an IT professional building solutions, a business user focused on innovation, or part of the academic community exploring cutting-edge technologies, this post is your launchpad into the world of SAP BTP.

Curious where you fit in? Keep reading to discover the tools, learning paths, and support SAP BTP offers for every IT role: from developers and architects to students, educators, and decision makers.

No matter your background or goals, there‚Äôs a starting point tailored just for you.

 

What We‚Äôll Cover Here

  1. What Is SAP BTP?
  2. Why SAP BTP Matters
  3. SAP BTP and clean core
  4. Try Before You Buy: Trials & Pricing Models
  5. Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?
  6. SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role
  7. Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates
  8. Start building today!

 

What is SAP BTP?

SAP BTP is an intuitive, modern development and innovation platform for both professional IT and business users. It is a unified platform that brings quickly together everything you need to build any idea or business vision to life, extending, and integrating existing business applications, whether they‚Äôre SAP or not.

With self-service data discovery, modeling, planning, and analytics for business users in a governed environment, it provides integration solutions to connect and streamline applications and processes across the entire enterprise, offering pre-built business content like built-in data products, integrations, workflows, app templates, and AI services.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs in the toolbox:

  • App Development & Automation: Rapidly develop applications or automate processes using low-code/no-code tools or opt for professional-code development when advanced customization and control are required
  • Data & Analytics: Turn your data into decisions with built-in analytics and planning tools.
  • Integration: Connect SAP or non-SAP systems like a pro.
  • Artificial Intelligence: Infuse AI into your workflows, apps, and decisions.
  • Platform Foundation: Secure, scalable, and ready for hybrid cloud environments.

Simply put, SAP BTP enables you to innovate and stay relevant by building on established foundations.

 

Why SAP BTP Matters?

Because digital transformation is not just a trend, it‚Äôs essential for adaptability and resilience, a.k.a. survival.

With SAP BTP, you can:

  • Automate repetitive tasks and free up time for real work.
  • Connect all of your systems, so they integrate.
  • Build custom apps tailored to your business needs and vision.
  • Use AI to make smarter decisions, faster.
  • Connect and harmonize all your data, eliminating data silos
  • Get mission-critical insights from your data without a background in data science

And the best part? You don‚Äôt have to start from scratch.
SAP BTP offers thousands of pre-built content packages, from application or automation templates to integration flows to dashboards to AI services.

 

SAP BTP and clean core

Clean core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing agile, innovative and efficient ERP systems. The principles focus on building resilient business processes and extensions supported by seamless integration, efficient operations, and data quality.

Central to the clean core strategy are Side-by-side extensions, powered by SAP BTP.

Side-by-side extensions allow organizations to enhance their SAP landscapes without directly modifying the core SAP S/4HANA system: instead of embedding custom code within the core, new functionalities, integrations, and custom applications are developed and deployed independently on SAP BTP.

This approach leverages SAP BTP's robust services, including various runtime environments (like Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment), development tools (like SAP Business Application Studio and CAP), and critical integration services (like SAP Integration Suite and SAP Event Mesh). Connectivity is securely handled by tools like the SAP Cloud Connector for on-premise systems and the Destination Service, ensuring seamless data exchange via standard APIs and business events from the core.

 

Try Before You Buy: Free Trials & Flexible Pricing Models
Not ready to commit? No problem

SAP BTP offers a 90-day free trial with access to 30+ services.

You can explore, experiment, and learn at your own pace how to build, deploy, and integrate with a full suite of platform services.

Start here your free trial of SAP Business Technology Platform.

When you're ready to scale, you‚Äôve got options:

  • Free Tier: Build small apps, pay only for what you use.
  • Pay-As-You-Go: Great for dynamic needs and innovation projects.
  • Enterprise Agreement: Predictable pricing for known use cases.

Explore all the possibilities SAP BTP unlocks. We‚Äôve outlined the opportunities below:

 

Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?

entry.title: How to create a new ship-to address and assign it to delivery on creation using exit in ECC?
entry.content:
User exit: MV50AFZ1

Routine: userexit_save_document_prepare

DATA: ls_adrc TYPE addr1_data,
ls_adrc_new TYPE addr1_data,
l_h32 TYPE guid_32,
l_handle TYPE szad_field-handle,
l_ag TYPE adrc-addr_group,
l_ret TYPE szad_field-returncode,
l_ref TYPE addr_ref,
l_nadrnr TYPE adrc-addrnumber,
lt_errtab TYPE TABLE OF addr_error WITH DEFAULT KEY.

LOOP AT xvbpa ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_vbpa>) WHERE parvw = 'WE'. " Ship-To
"Read current address
SELECT SINGLE * FROM adrc INTO @DATA(wa_adrc)
WHERE addrnumber = @<fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING wa_adrc TO ls_adrc."Copy default address values
"modify address fields here
"ls_adrc-street
"ls_adrc-str_suppl1
"ls_adrc-str_suppl2
"ls_adrc-str_suppl3
"ls_adrc-city1
"ls_adrc-post_code1
"ls_adrc-region
"ls_adrc-country

" Generate temporary handle
CALL FUNCTION 'GUID_CREATE'
IMPORTING
ev_guid_32 = l_h32.
l_handle = l_h32+0(16).

SELECT SINGLE addr_group FROM adrc INTO l_ag
WHERE addrnumber = <fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

"Insert new address
CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_INSERT'
EXPORTING
address_data = ls_adrc
address_group = l_ag
address_handle = l_handle
IMPORTING
address_data = ls_adrc_new
returncode = l_ret
TABLES
error_table = lt_errtab
EXCEPTIONS
OTHERS = 1.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful New Address insert

SELECT SINGLE appl_table appl_field appl_key addr_group owner
FROM adrv
INTO (l_ref-appl_table,l_ref-appl_field,l_ref-appl_key,l_ref-addr_group,l_ref-owner)
WHERE addrnumber = <fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_NUMBER_GET'
EXPORTING
address_handle = l_handle " Handle used in address creation
address_reference = l_ref " Optional: reference object
IMPORTING
address_number = l_nadrnr
EXCEPTIONS
address_handle_not_exist = 1
internal_error = 2
parameter_error = 3
OTHERS = 4.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful New Address number

CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_MEMORY_SAVE'
EXPORTING
execute_in_update_task = ' '
EXCEPTIONS
address_number_missing = 1
person_number_missing = 2
internal_error = 3
database_error = 4
reference_missing = 5
OTHERS = 6.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful save of New Address number
<fs_vbpa>-adrnr = l_nadrnr.
ENDIF.

ENDIF."End of if Successful New Address number

ENDIF."End of if Successful New Address insert
ENDLOOP.

entry.title: Oman localization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud: what matters for Implementation and beyond
entry.content:
If you are rolling out SAP S/4HANA Cloud in Oman, localization is not an afterthought‚Äîit‚Äôs your go‚Äëlive runway. SAP provides a dedicated Oman node on the Help Portal that consolidates scope, configuration, and reporting activities aligned to local law and practice.

What‚Äôs in scope

  • VAT: Generate the quarterly VAT Return using Run Statutory Reports, with predefined tax boxes for sales and purchase scenarios as well as reverse‚Äëcharge coverage for imported goods/services. You can analyze, adjust, export, and manage correction phases directly from the reporting task. 
     
  • Withholding tax (Form 18): Declaration focused on payments to foreign suppliers, supported by a guided sequence‚Äîmanage items, review, clear, prepare‚Äîplus parameters such as principal‚Äëofficer details. 
     
  • Cash flow statement: Produce the OM_CASHFLOW (indirect method) via the same Document and reporting compliance framework, using the OMCF financial statement version. 
     
  • Official document numbering (ODN): Enforce unique fiscal‚Äëyear serials for invoices and related notes through country key OM, document classes (OIN/OCN/ODN), number groups, and ranges. 
     
  • Postdated checks (PDC): End‚Äëto‚Äëend handling‚Äîreceive, present to bank/vendor, clear/bounce, reverse, and track history‚Äîusing the Bills of Exchange apps. 
     
  • Sales billing forms: Predelivered Oman templates for customer invoices and credit memos streamline compliant output.

Set‚Äëup essentials
Start with master data: maintain VAT registration numbers for company codes and business partners (format: OM + 10 digits). If applicable, define HSN/SAC codes and apply material tax indicators/classifications. Establish reporting entities and categories you‚Äôll run most often‚ÄîOM_RPG_ENT, OM_VAT_RET, OM_WHT_FORM18_DCL, OM_CASHFLOW‚Äîand complete activity‚Äëspecific parameters (for example, principal‚Äëofficer data for Form 18). 

Operate & report
Your daily driver is Run Statutory Reports: prepare the run, analyze and adjust, preview/ export, then (manually) submit to authorities and update the submission status. When you need corrections, open a new phase for a full or delta rerun as appropriate. 

Looking Ahead: E-Invoicing in Oman
Oman is moving toward mandatory e-invoicing, with a expected phased rollout starting in Q3 2026 most probably under the PEPPOL 5-corner model. This shift would require businesses to adopt structured invoice formats and integrate with accredited service providers.

Please read the blog for more details.

SAP Plans to deliver an e-invoicing solution for Oman as part of its continuous localization roadmap. Customers can expect capabilities aligned with OTA requirements, leveraging SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for seamless integration and compliance.

For the latest details and planned delivery timelines, Subscribe and stay tuned to SAP Regulatory Change Manager. This is your single source for official updates on regulatory changes and SAP‚Äôs enablement plans.

Takeaway
With pre‚Äëdelivered content across VAT, withholding tax, cash flow, ODN, PDC, and billing forms, Oman localization helps you cut risk and standardize close and reporting. Bookmark the Oman Help Portal entry and use it as your implementation playbook. 

Ready to make your Oman rollout smooth and compliant? Dive into the SAP Help Portal for detailed guidance and keep an eye on the Regulatory Change Manager for e-invoicing updates. Got questions? Share them in the comments‚Äîwe‚Äôd love to hear your perspective.

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Localization SAP S/4HANA Finance SAP S/4HANA localization as a self-service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Reference Architecture? [Summer Edition]
entry.content:
Before diving in, do you feel like you could use a quick refresher on SAP Reference Architecture? Then you should take a look at this Learning Journey: Exploring SAP Reference Content as Enterprise Architect. The journey is focused on how our Reference Business and Solution Architecture is part of the EA Framework (i), how it reflects the various E2E processes (ii), and how it is embedded into the respective tooling (iii). It is tailored for (aspiring) Enterprise Architects and anyone eager to explore our Reference Enterprise Architecture. Plus: After completing the journey and passing the quiz, participants will be granted a Badge. Happy Learning and sharing! üòä

 

SAP S/4HANA Breakdown in Modules

Let‚Äôs start with our first focus topic: The S/4HANA Breakdown by Modules. As you conduct business capability assessments or plan your transformation roadmap with recommended solution capabilities, you've likely encountered a familiar challenge. While many organizations rightly identify SAP S/4HANA as the central application supporting a vast number of business capabilities, a common question arises from business stakeholders and project teams alike: "That's great, but which part of the SAP S/4HANA solution is actually relevant here?"

For an Enterprise Architect mapping capabilities to applications, simply linking a capability like "Accounts Payable" to the high-level application "SAP S/4HANA" is often insufficient. They need to dig deeper for effective planning and want to understand which specific module within the S/4HANA Business Suite is required to deliver that capability. This level of detail is crucial in use cases such as scoping implementation projects, planning successors, and defining migration scenarios.

That's where the latest enhancement to the SAP Reference Architecture comes into play. This update moves beyond the high-level application view to provide a consistent, more granular breakdown of SAP S/4HANA into its constituent modules. For you as an architect and for your business stakeholders, this is a significant step forward, enabling more precise, transparent, and actionable architecture work.

To provide this clarity, we follow a structured, multi-level hierarchy, in line with the Application Component Hierarchy (ACH) for representing SAP S/4HANA solution components within our Enterprise Architecture models. Here, the solution component is at the top, followed by two levels of solution sub components. This approach is designed to be both logical from a business and technical standpoint.

  • Solution Component: The Application
    On the top we have the application. This is SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.
  • Solution Sub Component Level 1: Business Grouping
    The first level provides a logical, business-centric grouping of functionalities. Following best practices, this level leverages the familiar RBA Business Domains you already know, such as Finance, Asset Management, Manufacturing, Sales and many more. We have also introduced an additional L1 category called ‚ÄúCross Functionality‚Äù for capabilities that are centrally defined and used across many business functions, such as Pricing. It's important to note that this level does not reflect the technical structure within S/4HANA; rather, it organizes capabilities in a way that aligns with how you think about your business.
  • Solution Sub Component Level 2 (Module): Technical Building Block
    This is where we get into the technical substance. The second level represents the actual modules within SAP S/4HANA. These modules are subgroups within the Level 1 solution sub components and reflect the true technical structure of the solution. A module represents a group of solution capabilities that are technically bundled together and, in some cases, might be subject to separate pricing.

To ensure consistency and create a stable reference point, each of these Level 2 modules is mapped in a 1:1 relationship to an element in the ACH. The ACH is the official, tree-like structure within the SAP back-end system that organizes components by product and function from a business point of view. By anchoring our modules to this standard hierarchy, we ensure that our reference architecture remains synchronized with the product itself and allows other tools and functions to seamlessly connect and enrich the data. Learn more about the SAP Application Component Hierarchy here.

If you want to have a look at the SAP S/4HANA breakdown in modules yourself, you can do so in this Excel file. It also contains the link of the Solution Capabilities to the modules. The Excel file can be imported into SAP LeanIX. In the near future, the breakdown will also be available as standard in SAP LeanIX.

 

Extended Scope of Business Data Objects

As announced in the Spring Blog Post already, the SAP Reference Business Architecture now also covers Business Data Objects. With this addition, the SAP Reference Business Architecture increases its footprint in Data Architecture. And yes, with SAP Business Data Cloud the Domain of Data Architecture also becomes more and more important.

Let‚Äôs briefly repeat what Data architecture is all about: Data Architecture serves as a blueprint for how data is used. It is the high-level structure of data and data-related resources that acts as a framework for data throughout an organization, including models, rules, and standards. With efficient data architecture, organizations track the acquisition, movement, storage, security, and accessibility of data across their IT infrastructure. And this also depicts how we, as Enterprise Architects, can work with Business Data Objects: Business Data Objects are an integral part of Data Architecture. They can be defined as structured representations of business entities, such as orders or invoices, so that software systems can store, process, and exchange that information consistently.

Business Data Objects in the SAP Reference Business Architecture help to get greater transparency of how and which data flows across the different business processes. Business Data Objects are part of the SAP Business Capability Model and bound by Business Domain, meaning that Data Objects are systematically linked to Business Capabilities. This indicates for which Business Capability which Data Objects are required. Also, bear in mind, that one Business Data Object can be found in various Business So, on Business Area and Business Capability level, there can be overlaps.

When looking at the left-hand side of the below diagram, one can see that there is also a connection of Business Data Objects to Business Activities. The reason is that they can serve as input for or output of a Business Activity (e.g. when thinking of an ‚Äúorder‚Äù as Business Data Object)

 

Now the big news: Business Data Objects as part of the SAP Reference Architecture will soon be featured in the respective tooling. For now, users can refer to this publicly available Excel file, and import the content into the respective tool of choice, e.g. SAP LeanIX. While having Business Data Objects in the SAP Reference Architecture is a big step towards Data Architecture, the coverage of BDO‚Äôs is still increasing. We add Business Data Objects to the SAP Reference Architecture in a continuous manner.

Hint: If you are an architect and currently involved in Business Data Cloud, we highly recommend this webinar series, led by the SAP Enterprise Architecture Advisory Team and other knowledgeable and experienced architecture experts. You can find all the recordings and slides here: Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Archite... - SAP Community


Industry Content

Industry reference content is one component of the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework and it reflects SAP's deep industry expertise. Such content shows the integration of business processes and align them with SAP solutions relevant to specific industries. For example, the reference content is helping organizations to customize their business capabilities and processes to suit their very own industry-specific needs.

Using industry-specific reference architecture helps planning and executing transformations by utilizing pre-configured tools and aligning their processes with best practices and industry standards. Therefore, Enterprise Architects can derive significant advantages from industry content available through SAP Reference Architecture. They get comprehensive views, such as Product Maps and Solution Component Diagrams, allowing for holistic planning of system integration and deployment options, guide their transformation strategies, and ensure alignment with industry standards and best practices. Haven‚Äôt seen it yet? Check out the SAP Signavio Process Explorer here
 
For the time being, the SAP Reference Architecture is already available for a multitude of industries, which have been released over the past quarters. As of now, content for the following industries is live:

  • Consumer Industries including Retail, Consumer Products, Life Sciences, and Wholesale Distribution, with Agribusiness being added later this year.
  • Discrete Industries: including Automotive, High Tech, Industrial Manufacturing and Aerospace & Defense.
  • Energy & Natural Resources including Oil, Gas & Energy, Chemicals, Utilities, Mill Products, and Mining.
  • Public Services including Public Sector and Healthcare
  • Service Industries including Professional Services, Media, Travel & Transportation, Engineering Construction & Operations and Telecommunications, with Sports & Entertainment arriving later this year.
  • Besides that, there will be Financial Service content later this year, starting out with industry content for Banking.

To see industry content in action and explore how it is based in the Reference Architecture, make sure to check out the Enterprise Architecture: Automotive Example video.

If you are interested in learning more about Reference Business and Solution Architecture, feel free to reach out. Our team of Enterprise Architects is working continuously on elevating the SAP Reference Architecture. Kudos out to the teams within the SAP Global Content Group actively driving this!

Last but not least: Are you an Enterprise Architect and actively working with the SAP Reference Architecture? Then we would appreciate your feedback

entry.title: Re: RAP Behaviour Implementation get_*_features/get_*_aut...
entry.content:
If the Travel is open ‚Üí Delete button is active.

If the Travel is cancelled ‚Üí Delete button is greyed out, Update button also greyed out.

No messages are shown ‚Äî just proper enablement/disablement.

CLASS zbp_travel DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PROTECTED.
PUBLIC SECTION.
INTERFACES if_abap_behv_impl.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_travel IMPLEMENTATION.

METHOD get_instance_features.
LOOP AT keys ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

" Read status of the current Travel instance
SELECT SINGLE status
FROM ztravel
WHERE travel_id = @<ls_key>-travel_id
INTO @DATA(lv_status).

" Prepare feature result
APPEND VALUE #(
%tky = <ls_key>-%tky
%features-%delete =
COND #( WHEN lv_status = 'O' THEN if_abap_behv=>fc-o-enabled
ELSE if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled )
%features-%update =
COND #( WHEN lv_status = 'C' THEN if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled
ELSE if_abap_behv=>fc-o-enabled )
) TO result.

ENDLOOP.

" No need to fill reported here!
ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Scenario

We still have the Travel entity.
We want to control authorizations:

A user with role TRAVEL_ADMIN ‚Üí full access (update + delete).

A user with role TRAVEL_VIEWER ‚Üí read-only, no update or delete.

CLASS zbp_travel DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PROTECTED.
PUBLIC SECTION.
INTERFACES if_abap_behv_impl.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_travel IMPLEMENTATION.

METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
LOOP AT keys ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

" Check current user authorization (simplified example)
DATA(lv_is_admin) = cl_auth_check=>is_user_in_role( iv_role = 'TRAVEL_ADMIN' ).
DATA(lv_is_viewer) = cl_auth_check=>is_user_in_role( iv_role = 'TRAVEL_VIEWER' ).

" Prepare authorization result
APPEND VALUE #(
%tky = <ls_key>-%tky
%auth-%update =
COND #( WHEN lv_is_admin = abap_true THEN if_abap_behv=>auth-allowed
ELSE if_abap_behv=>auth-unauthorized )
%auth-%delete =
COND #( WHEN lv_is_admin = abap_true THEN if_abap_behv=>auth-allowed
ELSE if_abap_behv=>auth-unauthorized )
) TO result.

ENDLOOP.

" Again: leave reported empty
ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Say Goodbye to Overwrites: Experience Secure Dashboard Management with Edit Mode!
entry.content:
In the fast-paced environment of large organizations, multiple analysts often collaborate on a single dashboard, which can lead to accidental overwriting of edits and wasted effort. This lack of coordination makes it harder to enhance dashboards effectively. Fortunately, we have developed features to address these challenges.

A Seamless Solution for Enhanced Collaboration

Our edit mode and view mode are designed to facilitate seamless teamwork and eliminate common obstacles. With edit mode, analysts can work with confidence, knowing their contributions are safeguarded against concurrent changes, thanks to a locking mechanism. On the other hand, view mode offers business users an intuitive experience focused on filtering and data exploration.

 

How to Get Started

Getting started is a breeze. Simply open your dashboard, toggle on edit mode, make your desired changes, and save your updates to share with your team. This structured process guarantees that every modification is intentional and well-documented.

Capabilities Unlocked

  • Edit mode: Only one user can modify the dashboard at a time, preventing accidental overwrites and conflicting changes. This mode fosters transparency and teamwork, as other users are notified during editing. Plus, if your session times out or your connection drops, you are automatically switched to View Mode, freeing the dashboard for others.

  • View mode: Provides a consumer-focused interface for easy data filtering and exploration, tailored for business users who need direct, actionable insights. Users with the Consumer role can apply and remove filters to customize their view, gaining tailored insights without risking changes to the dashboard itself.

Key Benefits

  • Safeguard Edits: Analysts can focus on their work without the risk of overwriting someone else's contributions, ensuring every edit is preserved.
  • Reduced Overhead: The lock mechanism eliminates the need to coordinate edits manually, freeing up valuable time and resources.
  • Enhanced User Experience: View Mode provides business users with a streamlined way to interact with data, enabling effortless filtering and exploration.

These features show our commitment to providing a more efficient and user-friendly platform for process analyses, empowering organizations to collaborate effectively and work with confidence. 

Stay tuned for the release on September 23rd and get ready to elevate your dashboard interaction to the next level!

entry.title: Italy pre-configured Tax Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - issue with Tax Code X0

entry.title: Re: Posting Output Tax in Customer Down payment Request u...
entry.content:
With standard SAP limitations, FAZ billing type is configured with billing category P (down payment request) and posting status = noted item. This is hard‚Äëcoded to post only a noted item in FI ‚Äî no tax lines, no revenue. The tax code in FAZ pricing is normally ignored for FI posting.

Given your legal requirement and the fact you are in KSA/UAE, check if SAP GCC localisation for ‚ÄúAdvance Tax Invoice‚Äù is active and this is the cleanest, supported way. If not available, copy FAZ to a new invoice‚Äëtype billing document and configure pricing + account determination to post VAT at the advance stage. Ensure your final invoice pricing procedure is set to deduct the down payment from the taxable base.

entry.title: Re: BTP Service SAP Translation Hub - ABAP Texts transformation
entry.content:
Hi Patrick,
As you noticed, if your object list contains texts for which translations already exist in your ABAP system, SAP Translation Hub does not translate them again, but directly displays the existing translations with the Translation Provider set as ABAP. You can still edit those translations if required, but SAP Translation Hub does not directly make any changes to them, considering them already available and you are not charged for processing those texts.
To avoid sending content that is already translated in your ABAP system, you should configure your object list to include only the content you want to translate.

Please refer to the following documentation for information about the various options for creating object lists and consider the best approach for your needs: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/ceb25152cb0d4adba664cebea2bf4670/4647dd3f02db6a81e10000000a155369.html?version=202210.002&locale=en-US

Information about how to merge and edit object lists is also available.

Please also ensure that your object list contains texts in one source language only. 

Tip: You might also consider installing the translation object detective which can support you in determining which objects contain texts you want to translate. Documentation available here: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/ceb25152cb0d4adba664cebea2bf4670/88a3d3cbccf64601975acabaccdfde45.html?version=202210.002&locale=en-US
You can then use this information to create a local list (see https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/ceb25152cb0d4adba664cebea2bf4670/931091b61ce6482b9a40c1d68e93a29a.html?version=202210.002&locale=en-US) and subsequently create an object list based on the local list.

Hope this helps but feel free to contact our team at translationhub@sap.com if you would like to discuss our offering further.

entry.title: OIDC Authentication for SuccessFactors API Integration
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Requirement Overview:
We are working on integrating a front-end application with SuccessFactors. In this scenario, users log in through the front-end application and request their information from SuccessFactors. To enable this, we need to expose the SuccessFactors OData APIs to this application.

SuccessFactors OData APIs support OAuth 2.0 with SAML Assertion. The typical process is:

  1. Request a SAML assertion.

  2. Use the SAML assertion to obtain an access token.

  3. Use the access token to query the APIs.

Currently, for the SAML assertion step, we are using the /oauth/idp API to generate SAML assertions for our exposed APIs. This setup is working, but as per the official documentation (link), this method is considered insecure and has been deprecated, which may affect the APIs we expose to external systems going forward.

Proposed Solution:
We are planning to implement OIDC-based authentication for the APIs exposed from SuccessFactors to external systems.

  • We followed the official guide to configure the Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning services (link) and attempted testing using Postman.

  • During testing (Step 10), we were asked to select the ‚ÄúSAP SuccessFactors‚Äù application, but the option only works when ‚ÄúAdministration Console‚Äù is selected.

Further testing, as per this guide, yielded the following:

  • We successfully called the /oauth2/token API and obtained an ID token from the Identity Authentication service.

  • We made a second API call to obtain an API access token using the ID token from the previous step.

  • However, using this access token, we are unable to access APIs in the SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite. Getting the 401 authentication error while querying SuccessFactors OData APIs:

    Error Response:
    **********************
    {
    "error": {
    "code": "AuthenticationFailed",
    "message": "Authentication service failed to return token.",
    "details": "Failed to authenticated OIDC token"
    }
    }
    ************************

Key Requirements:

  • The official documentation suggests using grant_type=password, which we want to avoid for security reasons.

  • We intend to use grant_type=authorization_code so that users can log in via SSO through the front-end application, and their session can be used to access the APIs.

  • We would appreciate guidance on setting this up, specifically:

    1. How to configure the authentication flow for users logging in through the front-end application.

    2. How to configure it when an application (rather than users) needs to consume SuccessFactors APIs.

We request your help in setting this up correctly and securely. Leads to documentation/blog posts or any sort of help will be highly appreciated. 

@CarlosRoggan @DeepakGDeshpande @

Regards,
Pavan

entry.title: How-to export CI-DS Logs to external system
entry.content:
Is there any API which we can use to export SAP CI-DS logs to external system?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How-to export CI-DS Logs to external system
entry.content:
There are various log types in CI-DS:

  • SOAP API available:
    • Task or Process execution logs (trace, monitor, error)
  • API not available:
    • DS Agent logs: DSOnPremiseAgent log, job server logs, datastore specific logs (adapters, web services, RFC traces)
    • Security Log: Accessible from the CI-DS web interface in tab Administration -> Security Log

The task execution logs are the most commonly reviewed: trace, monitor, and error. There is a SOAP API available for CI-DS that can be used to extract those logs from active or finished tasks and processes.

Here are the general steps to interact with the SOAP API for that purpose.

  1. Make a call to "logon" to receive a sessionID
  2. Use that sessionID in a call to "getAllExecutedTasks2" to retrieve a list of runId's based on some criteria like task name or startDate.
  3. Use the sessionID and the list of runId's to make successive calls to "getTaskStatusByRunId2" to retrieve each page of each log for a given runId.
  4. Make a call to "logout" to end that sessionID.

entry.title: Re: Posting Output Tax in Customer Down payment Request u...
entry.content:
Try with the below approach

To have the system post VAT and customer A/R at the ‚Äúdown payment request‚Äù stage, you need to start from an invoice‚Äëcategory billing type (e.g., copy F2) and adapt it for down payment use:

Copy an invoice billing type to ZFAZ_INV. Most importantly, you need to change the Billing Category to "M" here instead of "P"

In copying control (VTFA), link your sales order type/item category to ZFAZ_INV with:

  • Copying requirement 20 (down payment request logic).
  • Pricing type B or C so AZWR is determined.

Include AZWR in the pricing procedure before tax, with account key to deferred revenue/down payment clearing.

Adjust the billing plan date category to use ZFAZ_INV for the advance milestone.

entry.title: Business requirement to copy SME Evaluation Questionnaire comments into implementation task
entry.content:
We have a business requirement to make comments from the SME reviews transfer to the task they create. Business reports that there is a lot of good information and clear instructions being missed because comments are not readily visible in change execution tasks.      

--- Steps to Reproduce ---

  1. Create New MOC Change Request.
  2. MOC CR is created and MOC Activities are also generated by system.
  3. Once the Initial Evaluation Activities are completed SME Evaluation Activities are populated.
  4. Under SME Evaluation Activities there are mandatory questionnaire to be answered with Comments as optional. If the users provide some information or add valuation information to be considered while completing the implementation of MOC. The Comments added during SME Evaluation should get copied to the implementation Activities Notes Section.

  5. MOC evaluation dependent implementation tasks are added to MOC Issue according to BRF+ decision table DECISION_TABLE_ACTIVITIES_2_C. MOC calls BRF+ processing at the system status transition from APPROVE to IN-PROCESS in this situation.

    The requirement is to copy comments from triggering question into Note section of resulting implementation tasks.

     

    API is available to read BRF+ decision table.

entry.title: Re: service item in US localization sap b1
entry.content:
thank you Faraz.. it has been confusing but now I got the solution:

and for future reference, since there is not a 100% clear explanation anywhere, here the solution:

 

SAP B1 version 10.02

Non inventory or non stock items can be created in the Master Data Item marking the only Sale Item or/and Purchase Item, as Felipe explained

 

The accounting tab in the items groups appears only when "Advance G/L account determination" is disable in the General setting for the company code. If this option is enable, G/L accounts can be customized in the advance G/L determination section, otherwise configure the G/L account at item group level when item group is created/modified.

when the item is being used in a Sales Order, it is necessary to mark in the logistics tab the Confirmed option, so the delivery is not necessary and AR invoice can be done from the SO.

 

thank you all !
